Trial_Design.evidence: Sixty-seven cyanotic patients (median age 15 months, interquartile range 6–49 months) undergoing corrective cardiac surgery were randomized

Participants.evidence: Sixty-seven cyanotic patients (median age 15 months, interquartile range 6–49 months) undergoing corrective cardiac surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomized to receive either controlled normoxic (50–0 mm Hg; n = 35) or hyperoxic (150–180 mm Hg; n = 32) cardiopulmonary bypass

Objective.evidence: Objectives: This study investigates the effects of controlled reoxygenation cardiopulmonary bypass on oxidative stress, inflammatory response, and organ function in children undergoing repair of cyanotic congenital heart defects.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Troponin I and 8-isoprostane, C3a, interleukins 6, 8, and 10, cortisol, protein S100, and alpha-glutamate transferase were measured preoperatively and 10 and 30 minutes after starting bypass, on removal of the aortic crossclamp, and 12 and 24 hours thereafter.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Sixty-seven cyanotic patients (median age 15 months, interquartile range 6–49 months) undergoing corrective cardiac surgery were randomized

Result_Outcome.evidence: Overall, troponin I and 8-isoprostane levels were lower in the controlled normoxic group (−29%, 95% CI −48% to −3%, P = .03, and −26%, 95% CI −44% to −2%, P = .03, respectively).
